Modify these instructions for how to create in Xcode: # Developing and Running a Safari Extension in VS Code This guide provides concise instructions to develop, convert, and test a Safari Web Extension using VS Code on macOS. It covers installing required tools, setting up your project, converting the extension for Safari, and troubleshooting common issues. --- ## Step 1: Install Required Tools Safari Web Extensions need Xcode to build and sign the extension. Also install Homebrew (if needed) and verify that the Xcode CLI tool xcrun is available. ### 1.1 Install Xcode Open Terminal and check Xcode: 
sh
xcode-select --version
If not installed, run: 
sh
xcode-select --install
### 1.2 Install Homebrew (if not already installed) 
sh
/bin/bash -c "$(curl -fsSL https://raw.githubusercontent.com/Homebrew/install/HEAD/install.sh)"
### 1.3 Verify xcrun is Available Check the version: 
sh
xcrun --version
If missing, reinstall Xcodeâ€™s CLI tools: 
sh
sudo rm -rf /Library/Developer/CommandLineTools
xcode-select --install
--- ## Step 2: Set Up Your Safari Extension in VS Code ### 2.1 Create a New Folder in VS Code 1. Open VS Code. 2. Select **File > Open Folder** to create or open your extension directory. ### 2.2 Create the Required Files #### manifest.json > Note: Remove the unused background section and delete background.js from your project. 
json
{
  "manifest_version": 2,
  "name": "Textarea Content Viewer",
  "version": "1.0",
  "description": "Gets the content of a textarea on the page and displays it in a popup.",
  "permissions": [
    "activeTab"
  ],
  "browser_action": {
    "default_popup": "popup.html",
    "default_icon": "icons/icon48.png"
  },
  "icons": {
    "16": "icons/icon16.png",
    "48": "icons/icon48.png",
    "128": "icons/icon128.png"
  },
  "content_scripts": [
    {
      "matches": ["<all_urls>"],
      "js": ["content-script.js"],
      "run_at": "document_end"
    }
  ]
}
#### popup.html 
html
<!DOCTYPE html>
<html>
<head>
  <meta charset="utf-8">
  <title>Textarea Content</title>
  <style>
    body {
      width: 300px;
      padding: 10px;
      font-family: sans-serif;
    }
    pre {
      white-space: pre-wrap;
      word-wrap: break-word;
    }
  </style>
</head>
<body>
  <h1>Textarea Content</h1>
  <pre id="textareaContent">Loading...</pre>

  <script src="popup.js"></script>
</body>
</html>
#### popup.js 
js
document.addEventListener('DOMContentLoaded', () => {

  browser.tabs.query({ active: true, currentWindow: true }).then((tabs) => {

    let activeTab = tabs[0];
    return browser.tabs.sendMessage(activeTab.id, { action: "getTextareaContent" });

  }).then((response) => {

    document.getElementById('textareaContent').textContent =
      response.content || "No textarea found.";

  }).catch((error) => {

    document.getElementById('textareaContent').textContent = "Error: " + error;

  });

});
#### content-script.js 
js
browser.runtime.onMessage.addListener((message, sender, sendResponse) => {

  if (message.action === "getTextareaContent") {

    let textarea = document.querySelector('textarea');
    let content = textarea ? textarea.value : "";
    sendResponse({ content });

  }

});
--- ## Step 3: Convert the Extension for Safari 1. Open VS Code Terminal and set the working directory: 
sh
   cd /path/to/your/extension
2. Run the Safari Web Extension Converter: 
sh
   xcrun safari-web-extension-converter .
This generates an Xcode project in your extension folder. You may need to grant permissions during conversion. --- ## Step 4: Build the Extension in Xcode 1. Open the generated Xcode project: 
sh
   open *.xcodeproj
2. Select the extension target. 3. In **Signing & Capabilities**, select your Apple Developer account. 4. Click **Run** to build and install the extension in Safari. --- ## Step 5: Enable the Extension in Safari 1. Open Safari. 2. Navigate to **Safari > Settings (Preferences) > Extensions**. 3. Find **"Textarea Content Viewer"** and enable it. 4. Enable **"Always Allow on All Websites"** if prompted, as Safari may block content scripts by default. --- ## Step 6: Test the Extension 1. Open a webpage with a <textarea>. 2. Click the extension icon in the Safari toolbar. 3. A popup should appear, displaying the content of the first <textarea> found. --- ## Step 7: Debugging in VS Code ### Reload the Extension After changes, rebuild using: 
sh
xcrun safari-web-extension-build
Then restart Safari. ### Use Web Inspector 1. Open Safari. 2. Enable Developer Mode in **Safari > Settings > Advanced > Show Develop menu**. 3. Right-click the extension popup and select **Inspect Element**. --- ## (Optional) Step 8: Package as a Standalone App If you want to distribute the extension: 
sh
xcrun safari-web-extension-packager .
This creates a .safariextz file for installation. --- ## Icon Requirements Safari expects specific icon sizes: - **16x16** (small toolbar icon) - **48x48** (medium) - **128x128** (large) If your icons do not match these sizes, either rename or create new icons. For example, if you have icons that match these sizes: 
sh
mv icons/text-box-30.png icons/icon16.png
mv icons/text-box-60.png icons/icon48.png
mv icons/text-box-90.png icons/icon128.png
--- Now you have a concise guide to develop, convert, and test a Safari Web Extension in VS Code. Edit files like popup.js, content-script.js, and manifest.json in VS Code, then rebuild and test the extension in Safari.

# Developing and Running a Safari Extension in Xcode

This guide provides concise instructions to create, configure, and test a Safari Web Extension directly using Xcode on macOS. It covers installing required tools, setting up your Xcode project, customizing your extension files, building and running the extension in Safari, and troubleshooting common issues.

---

## Step 1: Install Required Tools

Safari Web Extensions require Xcode to build and sign the extension. Ensure that the Xcode CLI tool `xcrun` is available.

### 1.1 Install Xcode

- Open Terminal and verify the Xcode CLI tools:
  ```sh
  xcode-select --version
  • If not installed, run: 
    sh
    xcode-select --install

1.2 Verify xcrun is Available

  • Check its version: 
    sh
    xcrun --version
  • If missing, reinstall Xcode CLI tools: 
    sh
    sudo rm -rf /Library/Developer/CommandLineTools
xcode-select --install

Step 2: Create a New Safari Web Extension Project in Xcode

2.1 Launch Xcode and Create a New Project

  • Open Xcode.
  • Select File > New > Project...
  • In the template chooser, under the App category, select Safari Web Extension App.
  • Click Next.

2.2 Configure Your Project

  • Enter your project name (for example, "TextareaContentViewer").
  • Choose your preferred language (Swift or Objective-C) for the container app.
  • Xcode automatically creates two targets:
    • App: A minimal host application for your extension.
    • Safari Web Extension: Contains the extension files.
  • Select a location to save the project and click Create.

Step 3: Understand the Project Structure

The new project includes:

  • Safari Web Extension target:
    • manifest.json: The extension manifest.
    • HTML, JavaScript, and CSS files for the extension (for example, popup.html, popup.js, and content-script.js).
  • App target:
    • A minimal container app that manages extension installation.

Step 4: Customize Your Safari Extension

4.1 Modify manifest.json

Open manifest.json in the Safari Web Extension folder and adjust as needed. For example:

json
{
  "manifest_version": 2,
  "name": "Textarea Content Viewer",
  "version": "1.0",
  "description": "Gets the content of a textarea on the page and displays it in a popup.",
  "permissions": [
    "activeTab"
  ],
  "browser_action": {
    "default_popup": "popup.html",
    "default_icon": "icons/icon48.png"
  },
  "icons": {
    "16": "icons/icon16.png",
    "48": "icons/icon48.png",
    "128": "icons/icon128.png"
  },
  "content_scripts": [
    {
      "matches": ["<all_urls>"],
      "js": ["content-script.js"],
      "run_at": "document_end"
    }
  ]
}

Note: Remove any unused sections such as background and associated files if they exist.

4.2 Edit Extension Files

Customize your extension files within Xcode. Below are sample contents for key files.

popup.html

html
<!DOCTYPE html>
<html>
<head>
  <meta charset="utf-8">
  <title>Textarea Content</title>
  <style>
    body {
      width: 300px;
      padding: 10px;
      font-family: sans-serif;
    }
    pre {
      white-space: pre-wrap;
      word-wrap: break-word;
    }
  </style>
</head>
<body>
  <h1>Textarea Content</h1>
  <pre id="textareaContent">Loading...</pre>

  <script src="popup.js"></script>
</body>
</html>

popup.js

js
document.addEventListener('DOMContentLoaded', () => {

  browser.tabs.query({ active: true, currentWindow: true }).then((tabs) => {

    let activeTab = tabs[0];
    return browser.tabs.sendMessage(activeTab.id, { action: "getTextareaContent" });

  }).then((response) => {

    document.getElementById('textareaContent').textContent =
      response.content || "No textarea found.";

  }).catch((error) => {

    document.getElementById('textareaContent').textContent = "Error: " + error;

  });

});

content-script.js

js
browser.runtime.onMessage.addListener((message, sender, sendResponse) => {

  if (message.action === "getTextareaContent") {

    let textarea = document.querySelector('textarea');
    let content = textarea ? textarea.value : "";
    sendResponse({ content });

  }

});

Step 5: Build and Run the Extension in Xcode

5.1 Set Up Signing and Capabilities

  • Select the Safari Web Extension target.
  • Navigate to Signing & Capabilities.
  • Choose your Apple Developer account.
  • If necessary, set up a development team and adjust the bundle identifier.

5.2 Build and Run

  • Select the appropriate scheme (usually the container app).
  • Click Run (or press Command+R) to build the project.
  • Safari will launch automatically with your extension installed.

Step 6: Enable the Extension in Safari

  1. Open Safari.
  2. Navigate to Safari > Settings (Preferences) > Extensions.
  3. Locate "Textarea Content Viewer" and enable it.
  4. Allow any required permissions, such as "Always Allow on All Websites", if prompted.

Step 7: Test and Debug the Extension

7.1 Testing

  1. Open a webpage that contains a <textarea>.
  2. Click the extension icon in the Safari toolbar.
  3. A popup should appear, displaying the content of the first <textarea> found.

7.2 Debugging

  • Use Xcode to set breakpoints in your extension code.
  • To inspect the extension popup:
    1. Open Safari.
    2. Enable Developer Mode in Safari > Settings > Advanced > Show Develop menu.
    3. Right-click the extension popup and select Inspect Element.

Step 8: Package the Extension (Optional)

To distribute the extension, package it using Xcode:

  1. In Xcode, select Product > Archive.
  2. When the archive completes, use the Organizer window to distribute your extension.
  3. Follow Apple guidelines for distributing Safari extensions.

Icon Requirements

Safari expects specific icon sizes:

  • 16x16 (small toolbar icon)
  • 48x48 (medium)
  • 128x128 (large)

If your icons do not match these sizes, rename or create new icons. For example, if you have icons with different names:

sh
mv icons/text-box-30.png icons/icon16.png
mv icons/text-box-60.png icons/icon48.png
mv icons/text-box-90.png icons/icon128.png

You now have a concise guide to create, customize, and test a Safari Web Extension directly in Xcode. Use Xcode to edit and build your extension, and then test it in Safari with the provided development tools.

# Developing and Running a Safari Extension in Xcode

This guide provides concise instructions to create, configure, and test a Safari Web Extension directly using Xcode on macOS. It assumes Xcode is already installed. The guide covers setting up your Xcode project, customizing your extension files, building and running the extension in Safari, and troubleshooting common issues.

---

## Step 1: Create a New Safari Web Extension Project in Xcode

### 1.1 Launch Xcode and Create a New Project

- Open Xcode.
- Select **File > New > Project...**
- In the template chooser, under the **App** category, select **Safari Web Extension App**.
- Click **Next**.

### 1.2 Configure Your Project

- Enter your project name (for example, "TextareaContentViewer").
- Choose your preferred language (Swift or Objective-C) for the container app.
- Xcode automatically creates two targets:
  - **App**: A minimal host application for your extension.
  - **Safari Web Extension**: Contains the extension files.
- Select a location to save the project and click **Create**.

---

## Step 2: Understand the Project Structure

The new project includes:

- **Safari Web Extension** target:
  - `manifest.json`: The extension manifest.
  - HTML, JavaScript, and CSS files for the extension (for example, `popup.html`, `popup.js`, and `content-script.js`).
- **App** target:
  - A minimal container app that manages extension installation.

---

## Step 3: Customize Your Safari Extension

### 3.1 Modify `manifest.json`

Open `manifest.json` in the Safari Web Extension folder and adjust as needed. For example:

```json
{
  "manifest_version": 2,
  "name": "Textarea Content Viewer",
  "version": "1.0",
  "description": "Gets the content of a textarea on the page and displays it in a popup.",
  "permissions": [
    "activeTab"
  ],
  "browser_action": {
    "default_popup": "popup.html",
    "default_icon": "icons/icon48.png"
  },
  "icons": {
    "16": "icons/icon16.png",
    "48": "icons/icon48.png",
    "128": "icons/icon128.png"
  },
  "content_scripts": [
    {
      "matches": ["<all_urls>"],
      "js": ["content-script.js"],
      "run_at": "document_end"
    }
  ]
}

Note: Remove any unused sections such as background and associated files if they exist.

3.2 Edit Extension Files

Customize your extension files within Xcode. Below are sample contents for key files.

popup.html

html
<!DOCTYPE html>
<html>

  <meta charset="utf-8">
  <title>Textarea Content</title>

<body>
  <h1>Textarea Content</h1>
  <pre id="textareaContent">Loading...</pre>

  <script src="popup.js"></script>
</body>
</html>

popup.js

js
document.addEventListener('DOMContentLoaded', () => {

  browser.tabs.query({ active: true, currentWindow: true }).then((tabs) => {

    let activeTab = tabs[0];
    return browser.tabs.sendMessage(activeTab.id, { action: "getTextareaContent" });

  }).then((response) => {

    document.getElementById('textareaContent').textContent =
      response.content || "No textarea found.";

  }).catch((error) => {

    document.getElementById('textareaContent').textContent = "Error: " + error;

  });

});

content-script.js

js
browser.runtime.onMessage.addListener((message, sender, sendResponse) => {

  if (message.action === "getTextareaContent") {

    let textarea = document.querySelector('textarea');
    let content = textarea ? textarea.value : "";
    sendResponse({ content });

  }

});

Step 4: Build and Run the Extension in Xcode

4.1 Set Up Signing and Capabilities

  • Select the Safari Web Extension target.
  • Navigate to Signing & Capabilities.
  • Choose your Apple Developer account.
  • If necessary, set up a development team and adjust the bundle identifier.

4.2 Build and Run

  • Select the appropriate scheme (usually the container app).
  • Click Run (or press Command+R) to build the project.
  • Safari will launch automatically with your extension installed.

Step 5: Enable the Extension in Safari

  1. Open Safari.
  2. Navigate to Safari > Settings (Preferences) > Extensions.
  3. Locate "Textarea Content Viewer" and enable it.
  4. Allow any required permissions, such as "Always Allow on All Websites", if prompted.

Step 6: Test and Debug the Extension

6.1 Testing

  1. Open a webpage that contains a <textarea>.
  2. Click the extension icon in the Safari toolbar.
  3. A popup should appear, displaying the content of the first <textarea> found.

6.2 Debugging

  • Use Xcode to set breakpoints in your extension code.
  • To inspect the extension popup:
    1. Open Safari.
    2. Enable Developer Mode in Safari > Settings > Advanced > Show Develop menu.
    3. Right-click the extension popup and select Inspect Element.

Step 7: Package the Extension (Optional)

To distribute the extension, package it using Xcode:

  1. In Xcode, select Product > Archive.
  2. When the archive completes, use the Organizer window to distribute your extension.
  3. Follow Apple guidelines for distributing Safari extensions.

Icon Requirements

Safari expects specific icon sizes:

  • 16x16 (small toolbar icon)
  • 48x48 (medium)
  • 128x128 (large)

If your icons do not match these sizes, rename or create new icons. For example, if you have icons with different names:

sh
mv icons/text-box-30.png icons/icon16.png
mv icons/text-box-60.png icons/icon48.png
mv icons/text-box-90.png icons/icon128.png

You now have a concise guide to create, customize, and test a Safari Web Extension directly in Xcode. Use Xcode to edit and build your extension, and then test it in Safari with the provided development tools.

markdown
# Developing and Running a Safari Extension in Xcode

This guide provides concise instructions to create, configure, and test a Safari Web Extension directly using Xcode on macOS. It assumes Xcode is already installed. The guide covers setting up your Xcode project, customizing your extension files, building and running the extension in Safari, and troubleshooting common issues.

---

## Step 1: Create a New Safari Web Extension Project in Xcode

### 1.1 Launch Xcode and Create a New Project

- Open Xcode.
- Select **File > New > Project...**
- In the template chooser, under the **App** category, select **Safari Web Extension App**.
- Click **Next**.

### 1.2 Configure Your Project

- Enter your project name (for example, "TextareaContentViewer").
- Choose your preferred language (Swift or Objective-C) for the container app.
- Xcode automatically creates two targets:
  - **App**: A minimal host application for your extension.
  - **Safari Web Extension**: Contains the extension files.
- Select a location to save the project and click **Create**.

---

## Step 2: Understand the Project Structure

The new project includes:

- **Safari Web Extension** target:
  - `manifest.json`: The extension manifest.
  - HTML, JavaScript, CSS files for the extension (for example, `popup.html`, `popup.css`, `popup.js`, and `content-script.js`).
- **App** target:
  - A minimal container app that manages extension installation.

---

## Step 3: Customize Your Safari Extension

### 3.1 Modify `manifest.json`

Open `manifest.json` in the Safari Web Extension folder and adjust as needed. For example:

```json
{
  "manifest_version": 2,
  "name": "Textarea Content Viewer",
  "version": "1.0",
  "description": "Gets the content of a textarea on the page and displays it in a popup.",
  "permissions": [
    "activeTab"
  ],
  "browser_action": {
    "default_popup": "popup.html",
    "default_icon": "icons/icon48.png"
  },
  "icons": {
    "16": "icons/icon16.png",
    "48": "icons/icon48.png",
    "128": "icons/icon128.png"
  },
  "content_scripts": [
    {
      "matches": ["<all_urls>"],
      "js": ["content-script.js"],
      "run_at": "document_end"
    }
  ]
}

Note: Remove any unused sections such as background and associated files if they exist.

3.2 Edit Extension Files

Customize your extension files within Xcode. Below are sample contents for key files.

popup.html

Ensure the popup HTML links to the external CSS file:

html
<!DOCTYPE html>
<html>
<head>
  <meta charset="utf-8">
  <title>Textarea Content</title>
  <link rel="stylesheet" href="popup.css">
</head>
<body>
  <h1>Textarea Content</h1>
  <pre id="textareaContent">Loading...</pre>

  <script src="popup.js"></script>
</body>
</html>

popup.css

Create a new file named popup.css with the following content: 

css
body {
  width: 300px;
  padding: 10px;
  font-family: sans-serif;
}

pre {
  white-space: pre-wrap;
  word-wrap: break-word;
}

popup.js

js
document.addEventListener('DOMContentLoaded', () => {

  browser.tabs.query({ active: true, currentWindow: true }).then((tabs) => {

    let activeTab = tabs[0];
    return browser.tabs.sendMessage(activeTab.id, { action: "getTextareaContent" });

  }).then((response) => {

    document.getElementById('textareaContent').textContent =
      response.content || "No textarea found.";

  }).catch((error) => {

    document.getElementById('textareaContent').textContent = "Error: " + error;

  });

});

content-script.js

js
browser.runtime.onMessage.addListener((message, sender, sendResponse) => {

  if (message.action === "getTextareaContent") {

    let textarea = document.querySelector('textarea');
    let content = textarea ? textarea.value : "";
    sendResponse({ content });

  }

});

Below are the modified files that implement the text area extension. When the user clicks the popup, the extension will query the active tab for the first <textarea> element and display its content in the popup. The following changes were made:

- In **manifest.json**:
  - Changed the content scriptâ€™s match pattern to run on all pages.
  - Added the "activeTab" permission.
- In **popup.html**:
  - Updated the markup to include a heading and a pre element for displaying the text area content.
- In **popup.js**:
  - Modified the code to query the active tab and send a message asking for the text area content.
  - The returned content is displayed in the popup.
- In **content.js**:
  - Added a message listener that looks for the "getTextareaContent" action and responds with the content of the first <textarea> element on the page.

Below are the complete contents of the modified files:

Filename: Resources/popup.js
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
document.addEventListener('DOMContentLoaded', () => {

  // Query the active tab and send a message to retrieve the textarea content.
  browser.tabs.query({ active: true, currentWindow: true })
    .then((tabs) => {
      let activeTab = tabs[0];
      return browser.tabs.sendMessage(activeTab.id, { action: "getTextareaContent" });
    })
    .then((response) => {
      const content = response.content || "No textarea found.";
      document.getElementById('textareaContent').textContent = content;
    })
    .catch((error) => {
      document.getElementById('textareaContent').textContent = "Error: " + error;
    });

});

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Filename: Resources/content.js
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
browser.runtime.onMessage.addListener((message, sender, sendResponse) => {

  if (message.action === "getTextareaContent") {
    const textarea = document.querySelector('textarea');
    const content = textarea ? textarea.value : "";
    sendResponse({ content: content });
  }

});

These modifications ensure that when the popup is opened, it sends a message to the active tab. The content script listens for this message, retrieves the content of the first <textarea> on the page (if any), and sends it back to the popup, where it is then displayed.

js
document.addEventListener('DOMContentLoaded', () => {

  // Query the active tab and send a message to retrieve the textarea content.
  browser.tabs.query({ active: true, currentWindow: true })
    .then((tabs) => {
      let activeTab = tabs[0];
      return browser.tabs.sendMessage(activeTab.id, { action: "getTextareaContent" });
    })
    .then((response) => {
      const content = response.content || "No textarea found.";
      document.getElementById('textareaContent').textContent = content;
    })
    .catch((error) => {
      document.getElementById('textareaContent').textContent = "Error: " + error;
    });

  // Add event listener for saving the current page content.
  const saveBtn = document.getElementById('saveContentBtn');
  saveBtn.addEventListener('click', () => {
    browser.tabs.query({ active: true, currentWindow: true })
      .then((tabs) => {
        let activeTab = tabs[0];
        return browser.tabs.sendMessage(activeTab.id, { action: "getPageContent" });
      })
      .then((response) => {
        const pageContent = response.content || "";
        // Create a blob with the page content.
        const blob = new Blob([pageContent], { type: "text/html" });
        const url = URL.createObjectURL(blob);
        // Create a temporary anchor element to trigger the download.
        const a = document.createElement('a');
        a.href = url;
        a.download = "page-content.html";
        document.body.appendChild(a);
        a.click();
        document.body.removeChild(a);
        URL.revokeObjectURL(url);
      })
      .catch((error) => {
        console.error("Error saving page content: ", error);
      });
  });

});

  if (message.action === "getTextareaContent") {

    const content = textarea ? textarea.value : "";
    sendResponse({ content: content });
  } else if (message.action === "getPageContent") {
    // Retrieve the entire HTML content of the current page.
    const pageHTML = document.documentElement.outerHTML;
    sendResponse({ content: pageHTML });

Safari Canâ€™t Open the Page Safari canâ€™t open the page â€œblob:safari-web-extension://510a066c-c87d-4628-844a-56ce7c02ba26/59a51d50-7bb6-44be-8459-7e131a771391â€. The error is: â€œThe operation couldnâ€™t be completed. (WebKitBlobResource error 1.)â€ (WebKitBlobResource:1)

Identifying the challenge

Iâ€™m encountering an issue where Safari blocks downloads from web extensions using blob URLs. Considering alternatives like File System Access API or safari extension API for file creation.

Managing file downloads

Faced with Safari's limited blob URL support, considering options like data URI via anchor elements or utilizing a background script to fetch and trigger downloads.

Enabling data URL conversion

Converting blob URLs to data URLs using FileReader is more feasible. This workaround provides a practical solution, especially for larger data.

Refining the technique

I'm focusing on enhancing the solution for Safari web extensions, suggesting the use of FileReader to transform blob URLs into data URLs, enabling downloads through anchor elements.

The error indicates that Safari is having trouble opening blob URLs from within a web extension. A common workaround is to convert the blob into a data URL before triggering the download. You can do this by using a FileReader to read the blob and then using the resulting data URL for your download link.

Below is an updated version of the code in popup.js with the workaround:

Filename: Resources/popup.js

js
document.addEventListener('DOMContentLoaded', () => {

  // Query the active tab and send a message to retrieve the textarea content.
  browser.tabs.query({ active: true, currentWindow: true })
    .then((tabs) => {
      let activeTab = tabs[0];
      return browser.tabs.sendMessage(activeTab.id, { action: "getTextareaContent" });
    })
    .then((response) => {
      const content = response.content || "No textarea found.";
      document.getElementById('textareaContent').textContent = content;
    })
    .catch((error) => {
      document.getElementById('textareaContent').textContent = "Error: " + error;
    });

  // Add event listener for saving the current page content.
  const saveBtn = document.getElementById('saveContentBtn');
  saveBtn.addEventListener('click', () => {
    browser.tabs.query({ active: true, currentWindow: true })
      .then((tabs) => {
        let activeTab = tabs[0];
        return browser.tabs.sendMessage(activeTab.id, { action: "getPageContent" });
      })
      .then((response) => {
        const pageContent = response.content || "";
        // Create a blob with the page content.
        const blob = new Blob([pageContent], { type: "text/html" });

        // Use FileReader to convert the blob to a data URL.
        const reader = new FileReader();
        reader.onloadend = function() {
          const dataUrl = reader.result;
          // Create a temporary anchor element to trigger the download.
          const a = document.createElement('a');
          a.href = dataUrl;
          a.download = "page-content.html";
          document.body.appendChild(a);
          a.click();
          document.body.removeChild(a);
        };
        reader.readAsDataURL(blob);
      })
      .catch((error) => {
        console.error("Error saving page content: ", error);
      });
  });

});

And here is the unchanged code for content.js (which sends back the page content):

Filename: Resources/content.js 

js
browser.runtime.onMessage.addListener((message, sender, sendResponse) => {

  if (message.action === "getTextareaContent") {
    const textarea = document.querySelector('textarea');
    const content = textarea ? textarea.value : "";
    sendResponse({ content: content });
  } else if (message.action === "getPageContent") {
    // Retrieve the entire HTML content of the current page.
    const pageHTML = document.documentElement.outerHTML;
    sendResponse({ content: pageHTML });
  }

});

With this change, instead of linking directly to a blob URL (which Safari may refuse to open), the blob is converted to a data URL that Safari can handle, thereby allowing the file download to work properly.
